title: Twins separated for 66 years thank Long Lost Family for making their lives 'complete'
text:

The first ever twins to be reunited on TV’s Long Lost Family said last night: “Our lives finally feel complete.”

Jennifer Wilson and Kathleen Millns met 66 years after they were separated as babies.

They discovered they had been living just three miles away from each other in the town they grew up in.

The sisters even shared the same doctor and dentist and their children attended the same school.

Their story was told in 2011 on the opening episode of the ITV ancestry show that reunites lost relatives.

Eight years later they have become ­inseparable – and they have told how their “twin telepathy” could not be stronger.

(Image: ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

For their 76th birthday in August they bought each other the same jumper.

Kathleen said: “I gave Jennifer the bag with the present in, she gave me the bag with mine.

“She pulled hers out first and started ­laughing and I pulled mine out and started laughing. They were both exactly the same from the same place. We do this all the time.

“Often, when the phone rings I can look at my husband Derek and say, ‘That’s Jennifer’.”

Jennifer had been told she had an identical twin sister by relatives in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, when she was a teenager and dreamed of meeting her.

She said: “The first thing I said to Kath was, ‘Oh I have missed you’ even though I didn’t know her. I’d been looking for that long.

(Image: We Love TV)

“We just clicked straight away, as though we’d never been parted.”

The sisters’ bond became stronger after Jennifer’s husband Howard died of sepsis in April. Distraught Jennifer had loved going on cruises with Howard and his unexpected death meant she cancelled one they had booked.

Kathleen stepped in and asked if they could go on one together.

At first Jennifer said no but changed her mind after daughter Nicole persuaded her and the pair set off on a Mediterranean holiday.

Jennifer said: “I didn’t think I’d go on ­another cruise. But Nicole said, ‘It’s what dad would have wanted’. So I called Kathleen back and we booked.

(Image: PAGE ONE)

“She’s always there to help me with Howard’s death. If we are in Marks and Spencer I can just say to her ‘I feel a bit tearful’ and she comes round from the side of the table to sit with me.”

The twins were joined by Howard on their holiday – in the form of a thimble sized pot of his ashes in Jennifer’s handbag.

She said: “I took Howard with me! He’s been all over. He’s been to see Bohemian Rhapsody and he comes to Marks & Spencer with us for coffee and cake.”

In a special episode of Long Lost Family, viewers will see how the twins have integrated into each other’s lives. They are filmed celebrating their 76th birthday with their families around them, before ­packing for their cruise.

Their favourite place to go is Marks & Spencer for a coffee and a slice of cake.

Kathleen said: “We meet up every Wednesday and we go shopping.

“Our first stop is a coffee in M&S. We look at the clothes when we’ve had a coffee. We love to sit and people watch as well, we make comments on people walking around and we make each other laugh.

“I was trying on a dress in a fitting room and it looked terrible but we were laughing so much the fitting room attendant asked if it was us making the noise.”

Jennifer and Kathleen were separated as babies because there was not space for twins in biological mum Eva’s two-up, two-down house. Kathleen, a former secretary, found out she was adopted when she was 21.

She wasn’t aware of any siblings and didn’t consider searching for any biological family until she was found by a researcher from the TV show.

But Jennifer was raised by Eva’s neighbour Elsie Paul, meaning she had close contact with her “auntie Eva” her entire life, going on days out and doing her hair for her.

When she was 13, a cousin told her that Eva was really her mum and she had an identical twin.

Elsie confirmed it but they continued to live as one happy ­family. Jennifer ­always wondered about her lost sister and often searched for people who looked like her.

She began proper detective work in October 2009. Her daughter Nicole, 35, posted her story on an adoption website which was spotted by Long Lost Family.

Before their emotional reunion in March 2010, shown on the programme in April 2011, there were plenty of “sliding doors” moments where their paths must have crossed.

Jennifer worked for years at Boots where Kathleen would come for her ­prescriptions and their kids were in the same drama group.

Jennifer reckons people were mistaking her for her sister before their reunion.

She said: “Once one of the girls I worked with came in and said, ‘Oh you’re stuck up, you.’ I said, ‘What are you talking about?’

“She said, ‘I shouted you yesterday in Sheffield.’ I said I was at work and she said: ‘My God there’s someone who looks almost ­identical to you!’

“Of course she didn’t know I had a twin, not many people did, and I thought yep, that’s who I’m looking for.”

In another bizarre ­moment, Kathleen realised she had met her mum once before, when Eva was working as a bus conductor.

Kathleen said: “I got on a bus one day with my children and a buggy. The ­conductress was talking to us and chatting to my daughter Julie.

“When we were getting off she asked to hold my son Richard and she cuddled him and loved him.

“I thought it was a bit odd at the time but when Jennifer told me Eva was a conductress and showed me a picture it clicked and I thought, ‘That was her’.”

The twins make up for lost time by attending big family events and looking to the future.

Kathleen has two children, Richard and Julie, with her husband of 52 years, Derek, plus four grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

Jennifer has her daughter Nicole, plus two stepdaughters, one of whom sadly passed away.

She has two grandsons and three step-grandchildren.

Kathleen said: “I said to Jenny when I’d met her that she should have been my bridesmaid and ­godmother to my children, but she said we’ve got to look forward and not back.”

And in the future, the twins see plenty of laughs, visits to family – and a trip to Center Parcs.

Kathleen added: “You’ve got to keep laughing, it keeps you going.

“As long as you’ve got things to keep looking forward to.”

■Long Lost Family Twins: What Happened Next, ITV, October 28, 9pm
